ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Deepened cultural understanding of German communities, how German inventions have helped shape the world, and a deepened understanding of the diversity and migration problems facing Europe and especially Bavarian countries.

I learned more German in this course than in L1 and L2 combined. I really enjoyed learning about German in more authentic settings, and I was proud to see how much I could improve in only one semester.

I learned so much from this course in such a small amount of time. I learned to speak German in a clearer way, use correct vocab, and my listening and reading comprehension improved a lot. I also learned a lot about the culture and histories of German-speaking countries and peoples, such as school systems and Nobel prize winners.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: German department has good access to tutors, etc. to facilitate German learning. Definitely take advantage! The department is always working to make the class more accessible, and sometimes they do a bit TOO much, but if that's the biggest problem with a class, then it can't be that bad.

Strengths: Allow for more opportunities to practice conversational skills
Weaknesses:  A bulk of the homework felt unnecessary and did not help improve my skills nearly as much as in-class discussions and conversations with native speakers.

I believe that this course's lack of tests took a lot of the stress out of learning a new language, and I believe that it allowed me to learn more German than I ever had before. Although it is a little unconventional, I feel like I have learned so much in such a little time due to this method. However, there was a very substantial amount of homework, especially compared to my other classes. I think to alleviate this, asynchronous days should have less time consuming assignments (i.e. shorter movies and questions), as they would sometimes take upwards of four hours to finish.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, this class helped continue to build a strong German foundation.
I would! If you're taking it, it's for a requirement. But it's not bad, and it's better than the intro level classes.
Yes. I learned a lot of german, received great feedback, and the professor is great.
